newsitem.title: USA: GE unit takes 21 pct Alliance Imaging stake.
newsitem.headline: GE unit takes 21 pct Alliance Imaging stake.

text.p: Alliance Imaging Inc said Thursday that General Electric Co has taken a 21 percent stake in the company after GE's medical systems division converted an $18 million bridge loan into equity.
The investment completed the final phase of its refinancing and put it in a substantially stronger financial position, Alliance Imaging said.

It said General Electric converted the bridge loan into a new series of preferred stock that is convertible into common stock at $6 per share. The conversion was part of an agreement negotiated in November, it said.

In connection with the conversion, General Electric received an option to convert up to about $8 million of Alliance Imaging's senior notes into a new issue of series E 4 percent convertible preferred stock, it said. The notes are not convertible until Jan. 1, 1998.
The bridge loan allowed it to cut its long-term debt by $21.4 million, raised shareholders' equity by $11.3 million and removed a number of restrictive loan covenants, it said.

It said that, it expects to make about $32 million in savings if the preferred stock is converted into common shares at the end of its 10-year term. The savings will come from reduced interest and preferred stock dividends and the elimination of requirements that it make prior debt repayments and redeem preferred stock.

Richard Zehner, Alliance Imaging's president and chief executive officer, said the company's improved financial strength now increases its capability to invest in new imaging systems and acquire other companies.
Zehner said his company appreciated GE's confidence in Alliance Imaging's management, noting that the preferred stock purchased was non-voting and did not require board representation rights.
The transaction also does not include any agreements affecting Alliance's futurer purchasing or investment decisions, he said.
